WRITING.TEXT: I just distract myself using any means possible - YouTube or sleep are my favorite distractions.
Me too. I feel like I don't fit in even in so-called "safe spaces" where everyone else seems to make friends so easily.
Honestly one of the reasons I'm still going is because there's always books coming out that I want to read. Can't read if I'm dead, so...

Me too - even on good days when I'm waiting for the train I think, well I *could* theoretically throw myself under it, but meh. I see rafters and think about hanging myself. It's less of an emergency than something that just happens and I don't really feel the urge to act on suicidal thoughts. Kind of awkward when I don't look before crossing the street and my friend jokingly says, "I'm a college student who just got an assignment back, run me over!" How'd you know what I was thinking?
Public transportation. Plus I don't have friends so I have plenty of time.
Learn and read and definitely enjoy school more. I would learn every language I could and specifics of historical events.
Requiescat in Pace.
November 9 by Colleen Hoover. I don't think I hate a book more than I hate that one.
Reading. It's excellent on public transportation.

I've had severe social anxiety and depression since 7th grade. Six years of being a teenager and I've spent most of it at home in my room, I don't even remember what I did most of the time. I made a couple acquaintances that weren't really friends. I missed my prom and after-parties. I've never had a group of friends before. I'm in my first year of college now and my social and emotional growth is so stunted that it's difficult for me to connect with anyone.
"What's up?" I never know how to answer.
I'm 18, still get children's menus at restaurants.

Got yelled at while walking in Paris for seemingly no reason. I've told people who aren't my parents, and most of them said, "It's probably because you're Chinese." On the plus side I'm the only person my parents know who didn't have anything stolen while in Paris.
Me too.

I've always been shy but in seventh grade I was bullied, generally by exclusion - people would act like I wasn't there and talk about me behind my back. I knew what was going on and they knew I knew what was going on. I just kind of stopped talking to anyone after that. I moved schools the next year, but that came with a healthy dose of severe anxiety that the same thing would happen. I had one friend at the school from before, but I didn't talk to anyone else. I was invisible and to me that was better than knowing I was being ridiculed. Rinse and repeat every year and now it's so bad I can't talk half the time I'm supposed to.

This happens to me a lot too, because one little thing triggers doubts which after a while turns into "I'm a failure of a person" and then I just want to sleep for the rest of the day. It's ridiculous really :/
I'm probably gonna end up not studying for two big midterms I have in two days.

I'm the opposite, I'm terrified of not knowing that I'm dying. Even if I can't do anything I'd rather just know. I had a period of a few months once where I barely slept because whenever I would start getting tired I'd start thinking, "This could be the last time I go to sleep." Not in a hurry to relive that (though I guess it'll be a while hopefully lol) I'd rather go the assisted suicide way - then I'd know beforehand AND not be lucid when that happens.
Scared shitless of failing out of school, disappointing my parents, and having nowhere to go in life.

I have social anxiety. Talking to people, asking strangers brief questions, ordering food, e-mailing people, phone calls, are all hell for me. I stutter when I talk because I'm so nervous, so I try not to talk much, and as for e-mails - I have to ask someone to send it for me (I write them out and have someone else press the send button because I can't do it)
In my experience telling someone in a bad situation "it gets better" doesn't help. At all.
I'm fine being anonymous on social media. Not fine with emails to people I know.
I did that in one of my classes, but the teacher was an expert in talking incredibly quietly. :/
Can confirm. We also bitch about Quebec and Saskatchewan.
I'm game for all Christmas carols.

I was fourteen and in the library reading when this college-age guy came up to me and started talking to me. (I'm short and look for my age, so he wouldn't have thought I was even in high school.) Anyways, he ended up asking for my shoe size, and puzzled, I replied. He asked if I could double-check, so I took my shoe off and I did, and while it was off he picked up my foot and started feeling it, talking about how he was an artist and needed to know for an art project. I was pretty naive and unassertive at the time so let this go on for about a minute growing increasingly uncomfortable and creeped out. And then I looked at his face, and he looked really excited. Pulled my foot from his grasp, put my shoe back on and ran off after that. It was really fucking weird.

Always. Doesn't help that I've had a great childhood and supportive family, it only makes me feel worse because I should be glad my life is so great. I always feel like I'm pretending to be depressed so I can continue being lazy. Frankly, it's ridiculous. But if I was really just lazy and not depressed, I wouldn't feel so guilty about it, I'd be happy about all my free time and put it to use instead of not wanting to do anything. I'd play video games all day instead of feeling too awful to even enjoy video games. I wouldn't think about dying all the time. I wouldn't feel like I was a piece of shit for going to therapy and wasting people's time. I'd be elated about pulling off a deception, but I'm not. So. I guess that's how I try to convince myself. Still. It's irrational but I guess that's the nature of the illness.
Best: Harry Potter Worst: Westeros
I did until I had three back-to-back 75 minute classes over lunch hours. I'm still uncomfortable, but I'm hungry, dammit.
iPhone charging cords.
I just lie down in my bed and watch YouTube/Netflix until I fall asleep.
